Are you a fan of the hit show Stranger Things? Silly me, of course you are. Well, here is a Hawkins Research Lab keychain (two actually) for you to print. I printed mine in glow-in-the-dark filament. Worked great. I now have several of these in various colors. I gave a few away to my middle school students but also kept a few. Soon I'l be adding more. I already recreated several of the buildings from the TV show. Something fun to do. Enjoy.

NOTE: The second one is in two parts so that you won't have to use any support material. The way it's designed holds together very well. Put some Superglue in the holes and attach the small part. It will hold together like two hydrogen atoms at the center of the sun.

title: Nexus 4 Charging Dock - Plus keys and wallet

description.text: This is a dock for charging the Nexus 4 using LG's wireless charger LG WCP-300 Qi Wireless (optimized position for the fastest charging). It also has a place for putting a wallet and two keychain hangers one on each side.

I printed it with black ABS using 0.35 mm nozzle and 0.25 mm layers. The print quality of my part was bad, but as I'm running out of black filament I decided just to let it this way.
If you want a tight fit or your printer is very precise, use it in normal size. If you want it looser just scale it to 103% or 1.03 x original size.

Mine didn't curl, but I can imagine that would be an obvious curling place.

title: Doorstop Exploration
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My mom has a store, and in that store, she has a couple of doors. One door, she likes to keep open with a doorstop. But a standard doorstop doesn't work. Even a larger doorstop she had made out of wood didn't work. So she stuck the two together, and that worked. But it was ugly. You can see the ugly doorstop in the diagram.

When I mentioned that I can 3D design and print things, she sent me a picture of the ugly doorstop, with a diagram showing the height, length and width. After converting from inches to millimeters, I had a plan. Super easy!

I created a single color doorstop, and that's what you see in green. It's super easy to print, and on my printer, the filleted edges print perfectly with no support.

Then, I wanted to really surprise her, by creating a two-tone doorstop that's exactly the same size! Now, I know my printer does dual extrusion, but dual extrusion truly sucks for most purposes, especially as it's implemented in your average printer. So I thought, and the dual-color (50/50) doorstop was the next iteration.

I designed the 50/50 doorstop, and had a few issues with the sizing of the male/female connectors - geometry, switching which one needed to be bigger (female) versus smaller (male), based on margins versus size. Plus, I had a little lesson in symmetry. After printing a few doorstop halves that didn't quite fit together (male too big), or that didn't fit correctly (I flipped on the wrong axis), you have what you see here!

I have four different versions: left, right, male, female. I made them this way so if you want to print two of the same color, and then print the other two of a different color, you can do that on the same bed. For example: left male and left female with one color, and then right male and right female with a different color. If you print it this way, they should fit together well. I don't know if this is the optimal way, but I know it works for me. If you want a single 50/50 doorstop, you could probably print the left female with one color, and the right male with another. Or, you could print left male on one, and right female on another. The main thing is, you have choices!

The difference between the male and female parts are fairly small, so there should be friction, but you may need to use super glue to hold them together permanently. I put two of them together and they were difficult to pull apart. The other two came apart semi-easily. I'd rather have them be slightly too loose than slightly too tight. Please let me know if you need any tweaks!

I have two more ideas: 1) a monogrammed letter in the side. These are the Williams College colors (purple and gold), so a nice big W on the side in the Williams College font would be nice. 2) A tri-color (thirds versus halves) doorstop, with a similar connector scheme. I may or may not end up doing either of these things. If you'd like a custom monogram on the side, please let me know. It's fairly trivial to add in using Fusion 360.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

30%

Notes:

A very easy print. No issues on my end. I think with some printers, and some adhesion methods, you may need to add "mickey mouse ears" to the corners, especially where the point of the doorstop touches the bed. Mine didn't curl, but I can imagine that would be an obvious curling place.

Easy Cleanup

I use PVA glue on my glass bed, so I just had to rinse that off, and it was done.

The best way to permanently adhere two pieces of PLA is with super glue (Cyanoacrylate):

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyanoacrylate

I'd say just put a few drops of cyanoacrylate around the male edges where they come in contact with the female edges, slide them together, and that bond will last forever.

Fusion 360 and Simplify3D

A super simple design. I used Fusion 360, made a single sketch, used parametric design to make the male and female connectors align perfectly (by making a "margin" around the edge of the piece, and increasing that "margin" slightly for the male side [making the male center slightly smaller]). I extruded to different heights, and created a fillet around the bottom and side edges. For obvious reasons I did not add a fillet to the inside (male/female connectors) or the inside edges.

Simplify3D does a great job of slicing and dicing, and it printed perfectly with my FFCP.

You will likely need 4 feet, 2 right and 2 left supports.  Furthermore, you will need four threaded rods of either 8mm or 5/16" in diameter.  They must be at least 50 mm length.  Finally, to be able to assemble the feet, you will need to thread the supports and the feet.

description.text:
I can't stand a messy rack. So I made a way to mount the monoprice (item# 15760) 5 port switch in a rack.

Tolerances are pretty tight on this item, unless your printer is really dialed in, I'd print a few layers of the side with the mounting holes and do a test fit on your hub. Also, insertion into the holder is pretty much a one-way operation, you may break your print if you want to take the switch out.

Openscad files included.

The 8 port switch (#15761) is very similar though the locations of the feet and mount points are different. Unfortunately, my printer isn't big enough to print one for the 8-port switch. I don't like releasing untested items, so I haven't added in the dimensions for that.

Lots of pictures so please look through them all!

Here is my entry for the Teal Drones Challenge. I call it the Manta-Teal.

I wanted to design something that accompanied the lines of the original Teal Drones top as well as made a statement that I have not seen in the FPV drone world – beautiful flowing curves. Usually drones are so mechanical and functional that we don’t see pleasing aesthetics.

When I started the design I quickly learned that I had to focus on a few key components and that is what led me to what you see here. I wanted to make sure that the components were also what Teal Drones currently uses. Of course there is the requisite Runcam Swift Rotor Riot Edition FPV camera under the canopy. There is also the supplied Luminier AXII 5.8GHz FPV Antenna. I felt these had to be used in my design.

From there it was about flowing lines and soft edges. I wanted something that almost harkens back to the Art Deco designs of the past with sweeping faces and substance. Soon I realized I was designing an old Bugatti, Locomotive, or Boeing DC-3. It really became organic and started flowing. This is exactly what I was after.

With the integration of the TX Antenna, I quickly followed the lines to a kicked-up exit in the rear which flows perfectly to “tail”. The addition of the FPV camera lens cover and twin-LED lights had me feeling like this was taking on an animal persona. I then added a couple exit points along the spine for electronics cooling and before I knew it, I had designed what I call the Manta-Teal. Like a Manta Ray, the body is designed for flowing through the air while maintaining a low profile. The enclosed FPV Camera allows for better flow while also protecting the lens from impacts. The symmetry and flowing nature alone are an amazing compliment to the original form of Teal Drones designs.

Should you want more than just a flying experience, you can take out the removable insert on the top of the body and use the provided Go Pro camera mounting system that I designed. I chose Go Pro as FPV Drone Pilots primarily use their products for capturing recordings during FPV flights. The mount supports both the Hero and Session versions that Go Pro offers. This of course could be changed to allow for many different adaptations for camera’s that are on the market today. The choices are endless and the mount can be too.

The exterior of the body is 2mm thick and retains the stock mounting points. There is also ample room inside the body to support electronics expansion if need be.

Whether it be 3D printed or injection molded, the Manta-Teal is a beautiful addition to the Teal Drones catalog.

Thanks for looking!
Jon

Go Pro Session Camera - https://grabcad.com/library/gopro-hero4-session-1
Go Pro Hero 4 - https://grabcad.com/library/gopro-hero4-silver-1

One piece of advice for those struggling with the crazy overhang for the loader (like I was), particularly on printers with only 1 fan blowing from one direction... title: DIY RC Street Racing Car: One Week Classroom Project

description.text:
We are finally proud to introduce the high performance RC Street Car V1! Designed with a lesson plan in mind, this is the ultimate one week project for any classroom or hobbyist. Though all the parts to get this car driving are included in this post, we've created Onshape CAD tutorials to teach YOU how to design most parts of this car as it was a key project of the Inventing Reality Summer 2017 summer program. If you're looking for even more Onshape and Tinkercad classroom tutorials, projects, and lessons, check out our Inventing Reality 2017 lesson folder.

Regarding the car itself, it's SUPER FAST, durable, and fun to both build and drive. All parts of the frame can be completely 3D printed, even the tires and gear! Therefore, it's super easy to fix and modify since all parts can be made with the click of a button. It is known to be able to do the "super doughnut" meaning that it does doughnuts so intense that it spins at a 45 degree angle when it does them. (explanatory youtube video coming soon)

Non 3D Printed Parts List:
-2430 7200kv 4P Brushless Motor & 25A ESC
-GoolRC TG3 3 Channel Transmitter & Receiver
-RioRand 9g Metal Gear Servo
-GNB 850mah 2s LiPo
-JST Connector Kit (the ESC comes with a T plug which will need to be replaced with a JST for the battery)
-14T 2mm Pinion Gear
-M5x150mm Bolt (for rear axle)
-M5 Nuts
-M5 Lock Nuts
-M5x40 Bolts (For front axles)
-M3 Lock Nuts
-M3 Bolt Assortment
-M2.5 Bolt Assortment
-625zz Bearings
-High Strength Threadlocker

3D Printed Parts

-Rear Axle Ruler: This part is simply a measurement device. Place it at the end of your M5x150mm rear axle bolt to measure how far to screw in your right rear wheel
-Rear Wheel Simple/Front Wheel Simple (PLA and TPU): these are the simple versions of the rear wheel. Instead of a complex tread pattern, they consist simply of rectangular flaps. These work surprisingly well as the tread flaps function like suspension which the car otherwise lacks. Note that all wheels need to be printed with TPU treads. For optimal results, print treads with ultraflexible Ninjaflex TPU. The center of the wheel should be printed in PLA for best results also. All wheels are mounted to their respective axles by two M5 nuts. A standard M5 nut should be installed on the inside of the wheel while a lock nut should be installed on the outside of the wheel. For the rear right wheel, add a dot of red loctite to both bolts to ensure it doesn't unscrew.
-Front Wheel Axle Mounts (sides 1 & 2): These mounts sandwich together to hold your front 625ZZ bearings to hold your front M5x40 bolts. You want to print these in the strongest material possible at 100% infill and at least 3 shells as they take most of the shock from bumps. Printing them in solid PLA will do just fine though.
-5mm Flange Spacer: Sandwich these on either side of your 3D printed rear axle drive gear ensure it stays straight and doesn't move. Make sure that the flanged part faces toward the gear!
-15mm Spacer: Install this spacer on the left side of your car's rear axle to space the left wheel from the body.
-9g Servo Mount: This simply bolts into the bottom of your frame and holds a 9g metal gear servo.
-Steering Rack: This connects to both sets of your motor mounts to allow your wheels to turn. Connect this rack to your servo arm with some thin music wire or a very stiff paper clip.
-ESC Mount: Mount these on either side of your ESC to keep it tightly locked down to your frame.
-Right & Left Side Guard Air Intakes: These optional side pieces pop into the M3 bolt holes on your bottom plate and can then be fastened to the top plate with M3x8 bolts. These not only help contain all of your wires, but also keep all sorts of dirt and grime out. Also, the air intakes direct airflow onto the ESC heatsink and motor to keep them cool.
-2430 Motor Mount: As the name implies, this allows you to mount your 2430 motor with M2.5 bolts. Additionally, both of your rear axle bearings pop into the side of this mount to be held in place. It simply bolts down to your bottom plate to be installed.
-Front & Rear Bumper: These bumpers will save you a lot of suffering and unnecessary printing. For optimal strength, print these bumpers in a very stiff TPU or nylon filament so that they flex a little bit but not too much. The front bumper is an essential piece for protecting your front steering mechanism which can break during a hard crash. These bumpers simply screw down to your bottom plate.
-Rear Drive Gear: This super simple 3D printed gear connects to your rear axle with a M5 nut. The gear should be printed in PLA with 100% infill and 3 shells for maximum strength. Surprisingly, this gear will last a very long time before finally wearing out! To install your gear, simply pound a M5 lock nut or regular nut into the gear with a mallet. Screw it onto the rear axle and fasten it with a dot of red loctite.
Base Plate: At the heart of your car, there's the base plate. We've included .STL and .SVG files so you 3D print, laser cut, water jet, or cnc your base plate in any material you want! For optimal results, laser cut it in some cheap 1/8" ply.
Upper Plate: To hold everything together and make this car even stronger, there's the upper plate. This screws onto the top of your front wheel axle mounts and onto the top of the rear motor mount. The side air intakes also screw onto the top plate. Just like the top plate, we've included both STL and SVG files so it can be cut/printed out of just about any material you like.

Onshape

If you're looking for an easy remix, don't hesitate to make a copy of our public document and you're set!

Have you ever wanted to design your very own high performance RC vehicle? Are you interested in 3D printing and modeling and want a fun, easy way to learn? Our comprehensive tutorial slide decks from the Inventing Reality summer program 2017 covers everything from the history of 3D printing to designing, printing, and laser cutting your very own RC race car!

Inventing Reality Summer Program 2017 Onshape Tutorial

During our summer program, this project was taught to students from 6-12th grade. For the first day, we introduced the project to students and distributed boxes of parts. Returning students immediately began designing the car from the comprehensive slide decks. We then introduced the basics of MCAD, Onshape, and 3D printing to newer students or those who wanted a refresher. Each morning of the week, we would give a short, 20 minute lesson on an important topic/idea of 3D printing or Onshape before students set to work on their projects again. By the end of the week, all students of all ages successfully completed the project with time to spare for races. Since everybody works at a different pace, students that finished early set up a miniature race course and obstacle course to test their cars on. With only a week to complete this project, we decided to give students certain parts which took us months to perfect to save them time and ensure everybody could go home with a functional car by the end of the week. We gave them: the rear drive gear, bottom plate, front wheel axle mounts, the 2430 Motor Mount, and the front steering rack. If time permits, we highly suggest having students design all parts from scratch.

Things we suggest encouraging to students:

  • Always triple check your design before submitting it for printing or cutting, but never expect to get everything perfect the first time. 3D printers are powerful because they allow rapid prototyping and make improving your design much much easier!
  • Only use the tutorials as a bare outline and guide. Try different things and see what works and doesn't work! This is what will make your car unique!
3D Print and Laser Cut Submission

When students are ready to submit their designs for printing or cutting, we created two simple submission forms which fed into a google spreadsheet for them to upload their files to and choose their print and cut settings.

3D print submission form example

Laser cut submission form example

Non 3D Printed Parts List

-2430 7200kv 4P Brushless Motor & 25A ESC
-GoolRC TG3 3 Channel Transmitter & Receiver
-RioRand 9g Metal Gear Servo
-GNB 850mah 2s LiPo
-JST Connector Kit (the ESC comes with a T plug which will need to be replaced with a JST for the battery)
-14T 2mm Pinion Gear
-M5x150mm Bolt (for rear axle)
-M5 Nuts
-M5 Lock Nuts
-M5x40 Bolts (For front axles)
-M3 Lock Nuts
-M3 Bolt Assortment
-M2.5 Bolt Assortment
-625zz Bearings
-High Strength Threadlocker

• 3D printing
  • Laser cutting
  • Onshape
  • RC mechanics
  • Voltage
  • Amperage
1-2 weeks depending on what parts students choose design

description.text: I know this isn't that detailed... like at all. So I will give you a detailed description. That rectangular prism is the taser, the cylinder in the back of the drone is a counterweight, then the big part is the drone plain top cover. I made this so that police can get people running away by electrocuting them with the taser. One thing this drone is good at is speed. With speed, the police can catch up to the person on the run if they are really far ahead. Also, when you are flying you have more mobility which is a good thing in this case. That is all I have for the summary right now, if you have any questions, ask them in the comments and I will try to get back to you ASAP. Thank you for taking the time to look at my project. description.text:
Once I did the bed upgrade by jopereira, my Y tensioner hit the bed and caused me to lose quite a bit of bed printing area on the back of the bed. Here is the link to the bed upgrade -> https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2436602
I really like it. I haven't had to relevel since I made the upgrade.

I designed this Y tensioner to fix this problem.

The Tensioner is based on this one -> https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2021999 by idig3d.
It is a redesign and I used his basic concept but kept functionality with his knob and pulley slider. I went ahead and added mounting holes for the vertical side of the aluminum in addition to the top horizontal. I also made the wall thickness heftier and obviously lowered the front edge where the bed was hitting.

I didn't recreate the knob and pulley slider piece. Just use the Y Tensioner link above to get those files. Idig3d's link also shows his concept for how to put it together and use it. All of that is the same and can be reused.

description.text: It is a small stand using bunkering.

Introducing the Real Teal! A muscle makeover for the #TealDroneChallenge giving the Teal a mean look as it cruises 80+ mph!

Features include:
Functional hood scoop
3 rear vents
Front Fender Flares
Rear Fender Flares
Front head-light section
Sleek midsection with front and rear bumpers
Aerodynamic Cockpit

Bring your teal to another level as you punish your competitors with breakneck speed and a fearsome new look! The headlights can also be modified to add LED lighting. All while keeping your internals as cool as ice with a massive shaker hood scoop and triple exhaust ports!

Inspiration was the Teal's natural blank canvas. Once I saw that it boasts 80+ MPH speeds I knew I had to infuse sci-fi looks and some functional muscle car aspects to elevate its "sleeper" look to a new height!

Thank you for considering my remix! Best of luck to everyone!

-Greek

author: snoopyteam

title: Stepper fan mounts for Prusa i3

description.text: I was struggling to balance voltage vs heat output on my steppers, and so, after a bit of playing around, decided to keep them cool with some 40mm fans. This has proved to be extremely effective. This 'thing' includes fan mounts for for the x-carriage and the extruder on my Prusa i3 (which came from http://makerfarm.com/ ). My extruder fan mount provides for a couple of air paths (primarily onto the stepper, but also down onto the j-head), as well as support for the rear of the stepper (which IMHO is a weakness in Greg Wade's extruder design, as the hot+heavy stepper is cantilevered off a relatively puny, heat-sensitive, plastic armature). The extruder fan mount is printed in two halves that are joined (rivets / bolt / weld) after printing (see first image).

title: Jack in the Box Turner for Assistive Switch Users

description.text:
Turn your Jack-In-The-Box handle with a simple DC Motor!

This turner prints in two parts and will hold a small DC Motor (in a micro-servo body) in the right position to turn the handle.

A complete guide is in the works at ATMakers.org, but the basic are...

1) Print both the handle and body in PLA (or whatever you have - no real drivers on material)
2) Wire 4.5V through a 3.5mm (mono) jack to the motor
3) Attach AT Switch to turn on the motor.

Here's a video showing it in action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OEFSgMxn5rk

author: Peck

title: Game elements for BattleCon v1.1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
*(V1.1) Cleaned up project, updated source file and description.

A collection of components for different BattleCon game sets with the intent to facilitate creating mods for the game (custom tokens, etc.) as well as printing replacement parts.

*(The source file is included).

This project covers the following sets:
-War of Indines Remastered
-Devastation of Indines
-Fate of Indines
-Trials of Indines

*Unless any drastic changes are made these assets should also cover new sets too.

I measured the sets different assets, modeled them in blender and exported them as .obj files. This should save some time when creating your own content. The blend file is also included to help with this as well, with export instructions.

For convenience, every asset is suffixed with the initials of the sets they belong to (-WDFT for example would mean that asset is common for all four sets).

The board may be impractical to print, but stuff like the board tiles, standups and various tokens should be helpful right off the bat as replacements or extras.

If this helps you make anything cool, let me know! I'd love to hear this is being useful.

Very High Quality (100 um)

Infill:

100%

Notes:

2hot6ft2 uses risers which allowed for a larger switch. I don't have the risers so I needed to find a smaller switch. I used a JBT switch Part # B 2 21 J1 XXX XX XX XX. It's a "B" series switch. The first "2" defines a DPDT circuit (you can use a "1" for a SPST circuit). The "21" is for screw mount and the "J1" specifies a rocker operator. The "XX's" specify the type of terminals, plating, color of the operator, etc., and are of no concern for the dimensions of the switch plate. Choose what you like for those identifiers. This switch fits nicely in the opening at the bottom of the printer (see pictures).

I printed the part using Very High Quality (100 um) for a smooth finish. I set the slicer for 100% infill density because I wanted the very minimum amount of flex when I pushed the rocker. If you print it flat, there is no need for supports.

Once printed, I screwed the switch to the back of the switch plate with tiny sheet metal screws. Then I attached the assembly to the bottom of the printer with CA glue. The wiring is the same as described by 2hot6ft2.

I included the Sketchup model file for those who need to modify the opening for a different switch.

title: Semi-Modular 4mm Bit Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Thanks for having me tonight, folks.

Since my first and very own screwdriver with bits-kit I've owned, I've always found myself in the situation that the bits were constantly going their way to valhalla. Like, where do they end up? Maybe they're working fulltime at some shady diner. Don't care, won't care.

But since I always ended up losing those little ****s, I've always bought new kits instead of individual bits - since those were always more expensive than a whole new set with the handle included.

And this is the part of the story where I came to design this thing. I hated searching through all the boxes and holders from the sets to ultimately not finding the bit I've searched for after all. I've hated not having everything in the same place. I've hated having to transport like 2 boxes for two bits. That was just plain stupid and I hated it.

And thus I present you the semi-modular bit holder for 4mm bits! victory fanfare

Each piece you print of this thing is designed to fit another piece, on each of its four sides - much like a puzzle piece, but... snappier. This way you can 'click away' the bits you need and let the rest be in your workshop or room or kitchen or caravan or... don't look at me like that, I'm just not judging.

Still not clear what I mean? Look at the pictures above, doofus. It's self-explanatory.

P.S.: This is final. If you want a regular-sized version, scale it up. Maybe it works, maybe it won't, can't say for sure.

remixed_from.title: Carriages for Anycubic Delta Kossel Linear Plus

title: Anycubic Kossel Linear Plus carriage tensioner

description.text:
Anycubic calls these belt tensioners.
Now I can too.
Be careful not to over tighten the belts.

The connecting rod mounting points are 52mm apart. You do not need the copper spacers.

I removed the original carriages and placed them next to my new adjustable carriages and tried to match the top screw height. It worked! I only had to slightly adjust one of them.
I used 3X20mm screws for the rods, I think the 25's are too long.

I used a 3X20mm screw for the tensioner. This gets me about 10mm of adjustment. That doesn't sound like much, but if you get the belts as tight as you can by hand, then tension them, it is more than enough. I think I have only used 5mm so far.

I was not too thrilled about my L shaped slider, but I couldn't see another way around that bolt. It works.

I copied and pasted my nut pocket but because of the orientation (I think) the tensioning nut pocket needs to be cleaned out a little bit, post print. The 2 on top are fine. For me anyway.

These are working well with my E3D V6 effector
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2640121

I printed these in ABS with 50% infill.

R1
I made 3 more, 50mm, 51mm, and 52mm wide without the added gusset.
Basically, I trimmed 0.5 from each end of the 51, and 1.0mm from each end of the 50.
These should work although I have not printed them and tested them.

title: Impact Gun Trigger for cheap air impact guns

description.text:
I created this part because the ordered replacement part for a quite similar impact gun (Einhell) didn't fit as nicely as the original one on my old impact gun (Mannesmann). Since many cheap impact guns are actually just rebranded and identical to this one and many of them tend to have a weak trigger, because it is the only plastic part on it, i decided to design the spare part and upload it here. Works fine for me.

You can see a technical drawing of the impact gun here (under the spare parts tab):
https://www.isc-gmbh.info/isc_de_en/spareparts/stationary-tools/air-compressors/dss-260-2-7.html
The trigger is part 40.

Hope this helps, even if you have a slightly different impact gun, i'm sure many parts are the same. My gun is at least 25 years old and they still build and sell it exactly like that under many different brand names.

LED array with 3DX

Just so we are all clear, the cake is a lie. Now that that is out of the way, this is a version of Wheatley from Portal 2. I have no affiliations with the creators of Portal or Amazons echo dot. Yes you read that right. This is no ordinary Wheatley. This should be able to hold an echo dot so you can talk to that just like you would talk to Wheatley. It also has a port in the back that allows for you to attach a .5" diameter rod so that it can hang. Will post pics when fully finished and printed. Made to fit echo dot gen 2. The full size of this is 6.3 inches in diameter. I suggest printing face down.

Update: 2/26/2018

Did you find the cake yet? Of course not but while you were looking I made Wheatley a heck of a lot better. Now prints in 2 pieces and there is a mount for it as well, I tried to keep it simple. I will add photos when I have the whole thing painted! Also I am missing the top and bottom bar, haven't figured out how to add them just yet. Stay tuned!

comments.text: this looks very cool! Does the Echo dot go vertically in the large circular opening? Or horizontally where his Eye is?
comments.author: Raider1284

comments.text: Thanks for your enthusiasm! I am currently working on supports to improve the print, consider the current posted version the alpha version. The echo dot should sit vertically behind the "eye" of wheatley. That is what the stands behind the eye are there for, to hold the echo dot in the correct location. Ideally the microphone will sit in the middle of the eye for maximum mic pickup. The reason it is this size is to make sure the echo dot fits behind the eye without disorienting the appearance of wheatley.

title: CR-10 Ikea Omlopp No-Fastener Light Bar Mount

description.text:
As the description says.

No fasteners, clip in mount for the Omlopp 24VDC light bar from Ikea. 15" bar works perfectly on my CR-10S.

http://www.ikea.com/ca/en/catalog/products/10290966/

Print 2-3 mounts in your filament of choice. I used natural PLA so it would not colour the light any more than it already is. Mounts are very solid and press fit onto light bar, and securely clip into the extrusion channel.

I didn't bother with the Omlopp power pack that Ikea offers, just found an old 24VDC power adapter and hardwired it.

Full Donkey is a remix of the Donkey Car reference hardware design.

https://github.com/wroscoe/donkey

This design has four legs just like a real donkey ;) The original Fusion 360 design has been manually converted to OpenSCAD which I find easier to use (maybe you do too). My current printing preference is a standard 0.4mm nozzle, 0.15mm layer height, and 18% infill. I have included a number of tests that you can use to tune the design to your printer.

Features include:

  • Recessed nuts on the bottom of the base plate which make mounting the battery easier.
  • Optional nut trays which make attaching the roll cage easier.
  • Discrete spacers for the Pi, servo, and camera boards to accommodate different screw lengths.
  • A roll cage that is strong enough to stand on if you are into that sort of thing.

Version: 0.1

comments.text: Thanks for the feedback Robert. Sounds like you printed everything all at once using the Donkey_Car.stl file. I included the Donkey_Car.stl so that you could see what it looks like mostly assembled.

title: terraPin ACE Pinhole Camera, Lulzbot Edition

description.text:
The terraPin ACE, Lulzbot Edition, pinhole camera is the culmination of years of my 3D printing and camera design work. I love my Lulzbot Taz4, and the ACE prints beautifully on it. This compact design will even print on the smaller Lulzbot Mini. The ACE uses 120 film, and shoots sixteen 6X4.5 exposures per roll of film. It is the little brother to the terraPin ACME and snaps together WITHOUT ANY FASTENERS, using sliding joinery. With the exception of the pinhole (which is easy to make), all parts can be 3D printed. Additionally, a standard tripod thread (1/4-20) is provided by a high-strength, replaceable printed insert or a metal flanged nut.

120 film, also known as "medium format" film, is widely available at photography supply shops and on the internet (Amazon, B&H, Lomography, eBay, etc). If you don't have a local photo lab (and don't develop your own films), you can mail your film away for processing.

The ACE is designed for a 0.23 mm pinhole, but 0.20 mm will work just as well, albeit needing a little bit more exposure time. I make my own pinholes (and you can too!), but you easily can buy a laser-drilled pinhole from many vendors on the Internet.

Pinhole Diameter: 0.23 mm
F-Number: f/135

Pinhole Diameter: 0.20 mm
F-Number: f/165

Exposure charts for f/135 and f/165 are included for common film stocks in the "Thing Files" for download.

I archive all photos I shoot with the ACME family of pinhole cameras on Flickr.

Hey Dual-Extruder Lulzbot Users!
Included, at the bottom of the Thing Files, are two STLs intended to be 3Dprinted simultaneously with a dual-extruder printer:
Dual_Color_terraPin_ACE_Lulzbot_Body.stl
Dual_Color_terraPin_ACE_Lulzbot_trim.stl
I suggest that the "body" STL be printed in an opaque black, and the "trim" STL be printed in Lulzbot Green. This is experimental, in that, lacking a dual-extruder printer, I cannot test this before releasing it to the wild. Any feedback on the printability of these files most welcome!

You can learn more about pinhole photography basics in the mini-zine "Pinhole Photography Short & Sweet" (download PPSS.pdf, in the "Thing Files" section)

Hey! Read This!

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 4

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20 mm layer height

Infill:

50-90% depending on part

Notes:

First and foremost, USE OPAQUE FILAMENT. ABS is fine, but PLA is prone to translucence. If unsure, use this OPACITY TOOL to assess the opacity of your filament. I maintain a list of tested PLA filaments and their opacities on that Thing page; If you find another opaque PLA, please share in the comments.

Knobs and winders do not demand the same opacity as the body parts. If you have difficulty printing high-quality winders, I have excellent winders for sale in my Shapeways Shoppe!

Two parts require high infill (>75%) for strength:
terraPin_Thread_Plug.stl
terrapin_oskar_winders.stl
(I use 85% infill)

The winders are the only parts that require slicer-generated support. I tried to engineer support that would make for a better part, but I can't beat the support structures generated by SLIC3R.

The rest of the parts kit should be printed >50% for strength and opacity. I use 66%.

terraPin ACE Pinhole Camera, Lulzbot Edition, parts diagram Parts Identification

A# - terraPin_ACE_Lulzbot_Body_Plate.stl
A1 - Camera Body
A2 - Top Frame Bar
A3 - Hex Pinhole Carrier
A4 - Shutter Blade
A4 - Trapezoidal Key
A5 - Cap Clip

B# - terraPin_ACE_Lulzbot_Cap_plate.stl
B1 - Left Cap Slider
B2 - Cap Insert
B1 - Right Cap Slider

C - terrapin_prime_film_clip.stl
D - terraPin_Thread_Plug.stl OR 1/4-20 flanged nut
E - terraPin_Index_Window.stl OR 14mm clear red disk
F - terrapin_oskar_knobs.stl (several alternates included)
G - terrapin_oskar_winders.stl
H - Printable_120_Film_spool.stl or use empty 120 film spool
I - 24mm "knob pins" (3mm filament)
J - pinhole 0.23 mm (f/135) or 0.20 mm (f/165) Make or purchase

Not shown - terraPin_Nut_Cover.stl (used with metal flanged nut)

for clarity, all references to LEFT and RIGHT refer to the camera when viewed from behind (the octopus side)

Tools and Materials

The following supplies may prove helpful:
Needle Nose Pliers
Xacto Knife
1/8-inch drill bit (can be drilled by hand)
Cyanoacrylate or Super Glue
Gaffer Tape
Cigarette Lighter
Flat Black Acrylic Paint
Rubbing Alcohol / Acetone
Scissors
Sharpie

Pinhole
If you make your own pinhole, brass shim stock works well in 0.001 inch thickness. You can find this at any "real" hardware store. A soda can will also work, but expect it to be a bit thicker. You can sand the aluminum to a thinner dimension. You will want fine - FINE - sandpaper for polishing the burr from your pinhole. I use 1200-1600 grit wet/dry sandpaper. One sheet will allow you to make dozens of pinholes. #15 Beading Needles are 0.25 mm in diameter and are excelling for making small pinholes. A pin vise is handy, but a small locking pliers works as well.

Follow THESE INSTRUCTIONS to make your own precision pinhole apertures!

Cap Assembly

There is a pair of web-like built-in support structures under the Cap Insert - the flat plate that is part of the cap assembly. This must be cleaned out prior to installing the winders. I pluck and twist with a needlenose pliers and then trim any remaining bits with an Xacto blade. Failing to take this support webbing out will cause difficulty winding film at best, jamming and damage at worst.

Remove all traces of support from the winders.

The sliding cap assembly is held together by the winders and knobs, which are pinned together. GENTLY drill out the small holes in the winders and knobs with a 1/8-inch bit. If the winder shafts are difficult to insert into the knobs, there may be a small burr or lip on the inside edge of the hexagonal hole - GENTLY trim this with an Xacto blade. Make two 24 mm long "pins" from 3mm filament. Tapering the leading end of the pin may be necessary to GENTLY press the pins into place.

The triangle on the top of closed cap provides sight lines for the angle of view. If the triangle is oriented such that it points to the front of the camera, the back edge of the triangle represents the film plane and the point in front locates the pinhole in the camera body. There are similar sight lines on the sides of the camera body.

Using a 1/8-inch bit, bore out holes in knobs/winders for 3mm "pins" Camera Body

Remove Support
There are two struts that support the overhangs at the bottom of the shutter slot, in the front of the camera. Remove these with a blade and trim any stray bits of plastic in the recess. The Trapezoidal Key fits into this cavity and holds the shutter and pinhole captive. Press the Key in place. It should require firm pressure to install; If it doesn't snap into position, there is likely some trace of support that needs to be cleaned out.

Remove tiny supports under shutter channel

Prepare interior
A web of fine threads may be present inside your Camera Body. If present, these must be cleaned out of the interior spaces in the camera. I have used wire brushes to clean these cavities, but lately I have good luck with filling the space with butane from a cigarette lighter, and igniting it. The Butane flashes and the threads evaporate. I have never damaged a camera doing this, but if you choose to do this, you do so at risk to self and camera. I still use a wire brush and compressed air to remove any loose debris. I pay special attention to the edges of the frame where a tiny hair will show in your photos as a small shadow.

PLA can be somewhat shiny and can cause internal reflections inside your camera that show as ghosts and odd colors. To minimize this, the edges of the frame (including the bottom surface of the Top Frame Bar) should be painted with a flat black acrylic paint. Pack a folded piece of paper in the space the film will occupy to keep paint where it belongs.

Tripod Threads
After the paint dries you can install the tripod thread. Use either the 3D printed Thread Plug or a flanged 1/4-20 nut and the Nut Cover. I have been using 3D printed threads in cameras for more than a year, and only once did one strip out. Printed with high-infill, the thread seems abundantly strong. A metal nut will obviously be stronger, but the camera is light and small.

Insert the printed Thread Plug into the recess inside the camera and secure with a piece of Gaffer Tape, crossways along the long axis. The tape will keep it from rattling loose. If it ever fails, you can replace it at your leisure with the spare from the terraPin_Thread_Plug.stl.

If you use a flanged nut, you may have to press the nut in place, or - better yet - pull the nut into place with a bolt and washer. Glue the the Nut Cover on top of the flange with several dabs of Super Glue, pressing it in place.

Film Indexing Window
When manufactured, 120 film is rolled onto a spool with a strip of backing paper. The backing paper has a long leader and has frame numbers printed on it, and these numbers can be read through a window on the back side of the camera. For the ACE, which has a 6x4.5 cm frame, the numbers will be visible in the indexing window when the film is loaded in the left side of the camera and wound on the right. You will get 16 exposures per roll.

Glue the Index Window in the circular recess inside the back wall of the camera. Glue the disc such that the raised circular rim is mated to the camera body. This space will keep glue vapor from fogging the Index Window.

If you don't have a suitable translucent PLA to print this part, you might be able to get a small sample from a filament manufacturer or from a friend. Failing that, a suitable substitute can be made by cutting out a 14mm disk from a sheet of clear red plastic. A binder or "report cover" can often be found at an office supply store. The plastic must be translucent enough to read a dollar bill's serial number through it.

Using a red window is mostly tradition, but having a pane in place keeps dust and chaff out of your camera. Dust is the sworn enemy of film photography! I like to keep the Indexing Window covered by a tab of Gaffer Tape, when not actively advancing the film, to minimize the possibility of light ruining my photos. I have friends who never cover the windows on their medium format cameras without experiencing light leaks. YMMV Film is precious; Tape is cheap insurance.

Install the Top Frame Bar
The Top Frame Bar will only fit in one orientation, with the arrow on top, pointing to the right, looking at the back of the camera body. Trial fit the BAR: Tip the Bar into position and snap it IN and DOWN. Ensure that the Bar is all the way forward and there is nothing on the back of the bar to scratch the film.

In the rare instance that it doesn't fit properly, remove and investigate; You must trim any material with an Xacto blade that interferes with a proper fit. Repeat as necessary until it fits perfectly.

Remove once more and apply a couple dabs of Super Glue in each of the recesses (where the "ears" fit) to hold it in place. Install the Bar and ensure that it is positioned fully forward.

Shutter and Pinhole Assembly

Shutter
The Shutter Blade slides in the shutter channel. When properly oriented, the hole in the shutter will be centered on the hole in the body when the shutter is fully open. The shutter will likely bind in the channel initially, but sliding the shutter up and down in the channel will loosen it up. In all likelyhood, The shutter will be loose enough that it may not stay open or closed by itself. To remedy this, GENTLY, CAREFULLY, SLOWLY warm the back side of the shutter with a flame ABOVE the hole, close to the cylinderical "finger knob", and put several degrees of gentle curve in the shutter blade. This tiny bend will transform the shutter into a spring that stays put, open or closed.

Putting a slight curve in the shutter plate will keep it from slipping

Pinhole Mounting and Installation
One side of the Pinhole should be blackened to minimize reflections inside the camera. A black Sharpie marker works well for this. After the ink dries, inspect the other side of the Pinhole for any ink on the front (shiny side). A tiny dab of rubbing alcohol can be used to remove unwanted ink. CAREFULLY center the Hex Pinhole Carrier over the Pinhole on the shiny (front) side of the metal. Take your time to ensure that the Pinhole is precisely in the middle of the Hexagon. The camera is designed to allow for a small variation in Pinhole position without affecting your photographs, but an off-center Pinhole won't look very nice.

When you are satisfied with the Pinhole's position in the Hex Pinhole Carrier, a small dab of Super Glue, under one edge of the Hex, will hold them together. Double check that you are still happy with the placement. Use a matchstick or toothpick to put a drop of glue where you want it. GENTLY hold the Pinhole and Hex together until the glue is dry. (Inspect your work one more time. If you feel you have to take it apart, a little acetone can be used to remove dried Super Glue from your Pinhole)

With a sharp scissors, CAREFULLY trim any metal that protrudes beyond the HEX Pinhole Carrier. Any metal sticking outside the 3D printed hexagon will likely wrinkle the Pinhole during assembly.

The Hex Pinhole Carrier fit into the hexagonal recess in the Shutter channel. The shiny side of the metal should face out, and the pinhole will be sandwiched between the Hex and the camera body. Slide the Shutter Blade into the channel, confirming that the Pinhole is centered in the Shutter's hole when fully open. If it looks "wrong", take it apart, and try rotating the Hex so that the Pinhole is centered left-to-right. When you are satisfied with your Pinhole installation, press the Trapezoidal Key firmly into place.

You Have A Pinhole Camera!

Notes on Shooting Your Pinhole Camera

  • Refer to the mini-zine, "Pinhole Photography Short & Sweet" (PPSS.pdf) for a basic tutorial on making pinhole exposures.

  • You will need an empty 120 film spool. If you don't have one, either print a spool (included) or obtain one from a friend or your local camera store or film lab.

  • To load your camera, unwrap your roll of 120 film. Handle it carefully so that it doesn't unroll. Pull approximately 6 inches of leader from the roll of film (SUPPLY) and tuck it through the slot in the empty spool. Wind the empty (UPTAKE) spool once or twice to secure the leader. The SUPPLY spool is inserted on the left side (facing the back) of the camera, with the film and leader unspooling in a clockwise direction. The UPTAKE spool loads on the right side, with the Film Clip, and winds in a counter-clockwise direction. Adjust the distance between the spools to fit the camera by tightening/loosening the UPTAKE spool. Insert both spools, ensuring that the top edge of the leader is below the Top Frame Bar. If the leader is caught, investigate and remedy. Orient the winders to fit into the spools and open the sliding cap. Put the cap on the camera and close the sliding cap. If any resistance is met, wiggle the cap back and forth until it snaps into position. Close the sliding cap and attach the Cap Clip to the center of the cap. The cap may fit snugly on the body, but, with use, it will eventually loosen up. If you misplace the Cap Clip, a bit of tape will hold the cap closed as well.

  • Advance the film to the first frame: Wind the UPTAKE knob until the number "1" appears centered in the window on the back of the camera. While winding, verify that the SUPPLY knob is turning; if not, the leader has come off of the UPTAKE spool. Open camera, investigate and remedy.

  • The knobs should be snug enough that the film will not slip between exposures. If your knobs are a little loose, verify that your film number is centered in the index window before making an exposure. If your knobs are very snug, wind your film with two hands, loosening on the left, winding on the right.

  • After making 16 exposures, wind the UPTAKE knob until the Supply knob stops being turned by the advancing film. Turn the UPTAKE knob a few more times to fully wind the roll of film. Open the camera, removing the exposed roll of film. The Cap Clip will keep the film securely wound on the spool - without the clip, your treasured photographs are at risk for light leaks if the film unwinds. Photographers call that a "fat roll" and it can be a disaster. Carefully remove the Cap Clip and wind the exposed film tightly on the spool. There should be a tab of adhesive tape at the end of the roll to secure it.

  • Take your film to your lab (or mail it, or develop it yourself!). Most film processing labs also provide scanning services so that you can share your photos here and on social media! Post a picture of your 3D printed pinhole camera too!
More Resouces

An encyclopedic article with cross references
A self-described comprehensive pinhole tutorial
Make your own pinhole
Pinhole Designer - an excellent pinhole design and exposure calulator. The reciprocity failure function is gold. Sadly, Windows only, but runs well under WINE.
Mr. Pinhole - More calculators and more links
Worldwide Pinhole Photography Day
A paper pinhole camera, 2D printed in a Czechoslovakian magazine, in the 1970's

Handmade pinhole 0.23 mm diam. Almost perfect!

description.text:
It is questionable if Thingiverse needed another hook to a hang trash bags inside of cars since there are several good ones to choose from. It is equally questionable if a person needs one at all, considering how easy it is to remove a head-rest and slip a bag handle around the rods. But, here's another anyway. This one is designed-for and will probably only work with the very thin plastic bags that are used in retail sales.

This hook is sized for 13 mm head rest rods. It is very light weight and takes less than a meter of 1.75 mm filament to print a pair of hooks. In practice it should support plenty of the light-weight refuse that accumulates inside an auto. The sample shown in the photos was printed in PLA, but they are undoubtedly the wrong material for summer use here in the Sonoran Desert.

If you print a pair of them, you might want to make one a mirror image (or just turn one over), so you can have the attachment points on opposite sides.

Update 11/24/17 I added a version with rounded corners in most places. With the edges rounded, there is less plastic in the hook and it is not as strong. It seems OK, but you might want to scale it up a few per cent or use more infill.

I didn't have any flexible filament so I whisked up this mold so that I could cast the tire in silicon sealant.

Just coat the inside of the mold in Vaseline to stop the silicon sticking, put a good bead of silicone around the SimpleSumo's wheel part, set the wheel on the pedestal, so the pedestal goes inside the wheel to hold it in place, then squish the outside shells into place and wipe of the excess. Put some rubber bands around it and leave it to dry.

remixed_from.author: DrLex
remixed_from.title: FlashForge Creator Pro front dual fan duct

description.text:
Hi Guys,
I'm using a PowerSpec ultra with Dual Flexion Extruders, when I made this switch I heated up the fan shroud and flexed it to drop the ends down a few more mm for better alignment to the nozzles with the new setup. This may not be an issue for anyone else but just in case I figured I would share it.

I would like to thank DrLex for the great design and make sure all credit for this model goes to him.

My changes the fan tips now sit 5mm lower than previously and I added a 2nd tab that fits in the first notch on the carriage to give a little more stability, in my experience the original design wobbled a bit but could have been a result of my printer settings. This does create a 90* overhang so I recommend support in just this spot.

** Edit 11/26/2017 - I found that I extended it too far and the duct was actually contacting my prints so I shortened it a bit, I believe this now sits 2mm lower than DrLex's original which was optimized for a 10mm "nozzle depth" making this version a 12mm "nozzle depth"

** Edit 11/29/2017 - Had some issues with print quality when I went to PC so I've made the body a little thicker and added some reinforcement to the secondary tab I added. Will upload pics of the final product when complete.

comments.text:
The first is to thank Mr. Lyman all your work. For me it is an idol that surprises me again and again. Wear weeks studying their draft extruder filament from V1 to V4 latter. But in my country between millimeters is used (instead of inches) and language, I'm a bit lost.
I can not see or understand that the internal diameter must be black iron Nipple. The Auger Bit is always 5/8" which corresponds to 15.88 millimeters. Reviews diameter 16mm Auger Bit I get?
What should be inside measurement between Auger Bit and black iron Nipple?
Please, I hope I can help. It's the only thing I do not understand.
Thank you very much and best regards.
comments.author: javibaker

comments.text: The auger bit I use does not fit correctly in the 1/2" nipple.  I first drill out the nipple with a 5/8" drill bit.  Then I use a dremel with a flex attachment and a grinding bit that fits in the nipple.  I grind down the nipple weld joint in the nipple till the auger turns nice and free.  Remember that a 5/8"auger bit is only 5/8" in diameter at the end.  After the end is cut off you find it is less.  Hope this helps.
comments.author: javibaker

comments.text: A clearance fit of 100-500 microns is ideal, and a fit go 500-1000 microns is acceptable. Beyond that and you'll see extrusion speed decrease.

title: Filament guide for Printrbot Simple (late 2013 wood extruder)

description.text: This guide keeps the filament centered on the hobbed gear as it is drawn in to the extruder. This resolves occasional issues with the filament riding up off the ridged part of the gear. The part is simply wedged in place. It is easily removed in order to change filament or make other adjustments. It may work free if the fit is not tight when the extruder retracts - try boring out the hole or tightening the fit. Intended for 1.75 mm filament and the late 2013 Printrbot Simple wood extruder. (Earlier versions had a different extruder design.) (See also this alternative, which better resists working free from retraction: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:265814)
I printed mine with 0.1mm layer height, 2 perimeters, 3 top/bottom layers, and 0.4 honeycomb infill. No supports required.

author: FourDogs

print_settings.Notes:: Should need no support if you print it upside down (wide end up).

description.text:
Dice tower based on plinko-style randomization and bottom exit.

I used the golden-ratio pattern to maximize the probability of dice impacts, the same way plants use it to maximize sunlight hitting their leaves. The posts pull the dice toward the center, increasing the number of collisions. A deflector at the bottom spreads the dice out reducing the chances of stacked dice.

I created this dice tower because I wanted one that puts the dice directly below it on the table. That way the dice don't go all over. You don't need a tray and they always land where you want them. This is great for games like dice masters, where rogue dice can be problematic and you have a specific location where you want them to end up. You pick up the dice tower to see what your roll is.

Another reason I wanted bottom exit is to resolve an argument I have with my wife. She rolls one dice at a time. When a follow-up dice changes the face of the first dice, was her roll the original one or the changed version?

This dice tower not intended to be particularly compact. It does a very good job of bouncing the dice around in random directions, though.

Notice that the wide side goes down during usage (It should be printed upside down, with the wide side up).

Printer:

Creality CR10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Should need no support if you print it upside down (wide end up).
I used freecad for this under linux.

comments.text: -so you have to lift this manually to complete the roll and/or see the dice after randomization?
comments.author: KCrobble

comments.text: Yes, that's exactly right. I designed it that way so there is no post-roll dice changes (where a later die changes the original outcome of an earlier die) and so there is zero chance of the dice messing up your game setup.  Useful for a game like dice masters, for example.

remixed_from.author: nracing
remixed_from.title: Swissknife : Shark fin for turtle mode

description.text:
This shark fin replaces the top plate of the BFight210 quadcopter. The main plate part of this is 3mm thick. The original included screws look to be long enough to hold it securely in place. The original zip tie holes are still place. They may be useful to zip tie parts to the top plate.

Why use a shark fin? First off, they're awesome. Second, if you're using BetaFlight 3.2 or later, this shark fin should keep at least 2 propellers out of the grass when you crash upside down. With at least 2 props out of the grass, you can use "turtle mode" to try to flip you back over and continue the race.

I printed this with PLA at 50% infill so it would work well as a replacement top plate. I flew this in very cold weather and broke the top part of the fin off in the first crash but that is most likely because PLA is more brittle in the cold. The top plate has held up better than the original carbon fiber top.

I used Cura to do the slicing. If you're having problems slicing it with another program, try it again with Cura. I'm still learning how to 3D design. The edges are pretty rough, but it looks pretty good printed.

BFight210 Frame: BFight210 Frame: https://www.banggood.com/Bfight210-210mm-Carbon-Fiber-FPV-Racing-X-Frame-4mm-Frame-Arm-p-1181906.html?p=6Z050013977120130325&utm_campaign=139771_1210911&utm_content=1081

50%

I made this to small you will have to take the extrusion off to slide it on or cut off the nubs. Sorry I just received my kossel clear to test this. A simple design to allow the KC to be laid on its side without damage. However this should work for any delta style with 15/15 extrusion. This should also allow for easy shipping/packing a delta for carry or insert a 1/2 x 1/4 inch neodymium magnet into the slot to attach acrylic sheet for a build chamber. This is symmetric so it will work in any orientation. This is my first design in so there my be a few issues to watch out for. 1) I don't have my KC yet so the measurements were taken of the incomplete sketchup file BELs released so some measurements my be off i.e. the standoff my need to be taller to prevent damage to the acrylic parts.
2) The screw holes will need to be drilled to match the screws (I don't know what size fits the slot nuts).
3) The locking "bumps" may be to tall or the plastic not give enough to allow the part to be placed on the aluminum extrusion. Please let me know if you find problems with my design.

Print of a set of 4 for each side. Print a total of 12 if you plain on building a trifold carry case or build chamber. Note there are two versions.
The one with slot is intended for the magnetically attached acrylic sheets. The magnets I plain to use are http://amzn.com/B001KUURP2. These should be glued in place. The acrylic sheet should have washers glued in place above the magnets.

This is an accessory that can be threaded onto a hoodie drawstring to prevent the string from being pulled up into the abyss that is the hood.

Installation
Push the plastic-encased end of a drawstring through the top hole and push it all the way in. A tiny screwdriver can be helpful for this. Once the end appears at the other end of the part, it can be pulled the rest of the way with a pliers, needle-nose works best.

Part can be threaded all the way onto the string, or left on the end.

If the part fits loosely or the hole is not big enough, I will be willing to upload a file with a differently sized hole if you can tell me how much bigger or smaller it needs to be, and you ask me nicely :)

Printing
It is best to print this part using ABS or another material with high heat tolerance due to the tendency of hoodies and jackets to get left in cars that may become excessively hot inside, and PLA won't stand up to that environment.. Best results come with a glass bed, as the rough finish caused by buildtak can make your piece look unfinished if you don't finish it yourself.

I found it best to print with supports only supporting the line at the top of the logo, and without a raft. Supports are easily removed with a needle nose pliers.

Precautions
Remove the stoppers before washing or drying (or any other environments with high temperatures) to avoid melting the part and posing a fire risk.

Many thanks to jimflint80 for modeling the logo I remixed for this Thing!

title: Single-Layer Visual Print Bed Leveling Assistance Calibration Pane

description.text:
This thing is what I use to level my printer's printing bed when using filaments that aren't completely opaque at .2mm. This will print a .2mm thick '+' shape on the print bed that will be thinner where the build plate is too close to the nozzle, and thicker where it is too far away. The thinning will visible occur in a pattern leading towards the screw that needs to be tightened. If you notice multiple areas of thin application that are not connected to each other at all, it could indicate that your build plate is warping, that the build tak or other cover you are using is not level, or has not been applied properly, or that one of the rods moving the extruder carriage has been damaged.

Upon request I will create other versions of this model.

Game Decor has partnered with a very talented 3D artist under the banner of “DungeonWorks” and is going to be launching a Kickstarter for a new line of high resolution 3D printer files for modular dungeons and accessories. There are currently 3 lines of models with a total of 7 uniquely themed dungeons containing over 400 models planned for release. The first line consists of locations of classic encounters, such as the gothic stone dungeon, the dank caverns, and the half timbered town, all of which is easily compatible among the majority of fantasy settings. The second line is inspired by iconic computer based dungeon crawling role playing games where legendary settings are yours to design. The third line is driven by a high fantasy setting with tales of epic proportions. Several more themes and expansions for each line are planned to be released afterwards.

A little info about the 3 lines

“Classic Encounters” includes all your generic, classic settings. Basic dungeon, taverns, caves, city streets.

“Vintage Vault” is about recreating those classic video games and even board games. Everything in the game is recreated here in tile form. Relive the adventures of old or create new ones.

“Lost Realms” are deluxe sets. They're created just like a D&D module. There is an adventure theme already set out for a DM to build upon. So, these sets are heavily themed for instant adventuring.

This is a guide to help apply the tail fins to paper and tape rockets used on 1/2" NPT launch tubes. Our free to download template can be found here:
https://www.airrocketworks.com/wp/standard-template/

The NASA templates can be found here:
https://www.airrocketworks.com/wp/nasa-kennedy-space-center-templates/

There are two ways to use this fin guide, use one side of the guide for straight fins, or use the other side for 5° angled fins to make the rocket spin. Start by building the rocket body tube, then load the PVC mandrel into the center of the guide. Slide the body tube down to a comfortable working height. Fold the fins, and apply tape to one side of each fin. Tuck the flap without tape between the body and the fin guide. Once aligned, smooth down the tape on the other flap. Once all three are taped, remove the mandrel and rocket, and apply tape on the other side of the fin to fully secure it.

Note that the rocket shown in the picture has multiple launches, which explains the somewhat crumpled nosecone... I should really get a better picture.

A way to improve the resolution of the 3Drag / K8200 printer is by changing the extruder. One cost-effective alternative is to use an MK8 extruder with a 0.4/0.3 mm nozzle.

Currently, there are different ways to attach the extruder to the printer, here I propose a different approach where a single 3D printed clamp is required.

Since I'm interested in recycling as many parts as I can from the original printer (see for example https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1729453), the clamp is fixed to the metal plaque that supports the original extruder by using two screws.

The support has proven to be robust and simple. I have printed a first model in PLA that required sanding in order to fit the stepper motor inside.

Materials

2 x M3 screws (recycled)
1 x M4 screw + bolt

description.text:
I broke one of the garden hose adapters so I decided to design my own and print one.

ABS Print came out perfect. Using 4 perimeter/shells really made it stronger.

UPDATE: I made some minor adjustments. Please download the new .stl file

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

Material: ABS
Outline/Perimeter Shells: 4

USE MORE TOP SOLID LAYERS

I used 3 top solid layers, I should've used more when slicing. When I did a pressure test, tiny bursts of water was coming out of the flat surface. After smoothing with acetone, it fixed it.

For supports, I used automatically generated supports by Simplify 3D (pillar res: 4.5mm/angle:45 deg)

The male part might seems to be a bit tighter than an adapter from the local hardware store but it's actually a snug fit that won't come off due to water pressure.

Water Pressure (see video)

The video shows the pressure test without acetone smoothing. Please ignore the water leaking/pouring from the top of the tap thread, that's actually my broken tap. As you can see the part is fully functional.

Pressure Test Acetone Smoothing

I used a Moccona coffee glass jar to do the acetone smoothing. I wet a paper towel with acetone and spread the towel inside the jar. Then I placed the printed part on aluminium foil and placed it carefully in the jar. Left the jar semi closed for about 5-10 inside my 3D printer enclosure. (it has a fume extractor)

DO THIS IN A HIGHLY VENTILATED AREA

Washer/O-Ring

Insert a rubber washer inside the female part, and insert an o-ring into the male part. (See photos)
I saw something similar on Pinterest, so I tried to make my own.

description.text:
Some valence clips broke and needed to be replaced. Instead of doing the quick, easy, inexpensive thing (a 12 pack is about $6 online) I spent a few hours learning about software I've never really used before and made a few on my 3D printer.

They are a bit bigger than the originals, but clip right onto a 2.5" valence. When you flex them the outer wall delaminates from the infill a bit in the middle, but they are still strong enough for their task.

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.175mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Made with Monoprice natural color PLA Plus+
Heated bed: off
Nozzle temp: 210°C
Maybe a higher nozzle temp would help the walls stick to the infill a little better? Some other setting?

Turn a photo into a 3D extruded shape

I plan to put a more detailed description here in the future, but here's the overview:

  1. Took a photo of the part on a plain white piece of paper.
  2. Opened in the GIMP, drew a path that outlined the shape, filled the inside of the part with black and filled the entire background with white. Saved as a png.
  3. Imported png into Inkscape. Used the Trace Bitmap command to make a vector graphic the same shape as the bitmap. Deleted the image and saved as an svg.
  4. Imported svg into Blender. Extruded the thickness. Saved as an stl.
  5. Opened in Cura. Scaled to make it the right size. Put three next to each other and printed.

author: pipper21

description.text:
It is common for the arms to break on these particular headsets. The plastic used for the arms is ill suited. It becomes brittle and cracks. I repaired mine several times using friction welding (rotary tool with ABS filament), but they kept breaking in new places.

I found a youtube video where someone had printed a replacement part, and he was kind enough to share his model. Whilst it was a good model, it required a lot of support material (which means a lot of cleanup), and OpenSCAD would not accept it. I loaded it in meshmixer and split it into multiple parts and saved them separately. Once I had done that OpenSCAD could take the two parts and happily combine them.

I took his model and modified it so that it could be printed in 2 parts (which works fine for its use case) without any slicer added support. I did have to build in some support for the arms, but I made that part of the model. I left an empty layer between the support and the arms which made them break off quite cleanly. The result worked well and seems to be much stronger than the original. Time will tell how it stands up to the punishment of a teenager...

title: Tomb of the Griffin Knights - Cathedral Sample Pack 1

description.text:
Tomb of the Griffin Knights - Cathedral Sample Pack for LIVE KS going now. Please come check it out. 400+ models. https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/klingbeil/dungeonworks-3d-printing-modular-fantasy-dungeon-t?ref=340347&token=367e2da5

::UPDATE:: The design has since changed to a tri locking system. So now each side has 3 ports.

Please note to print the floors standing up. The surface detail is so much better when you doing it standing and you can print more at a time since it saves space.

Game Decor has partnered with a very talented 3D artist under the banner of “DungeonWorks” and is going to be launching a Kickstarter for a new line of high resolution 3D printer files for modular dungeons and accessories. There are currently 3 lines of models with a total of 7 uniquely themed dungeons containing over 400 models planned for release. The first line consists of locations of classic encounters, such as the gothic stone dungeon, the dank caverns, and the half timbered town, all of which is easily compatible among the majority of fantasy settings. The second line is inspired by iconic computer based dungeon crawling role playing games where legendary settings are yours to design. The third line is driven by a high fantasy setting with tales of epic proportions. Several more themes and expansions for each line are planned to be released afterwards.

A little info about the 3 lines

“Classic Encounters” includes all your generic, classic settings. Basic dungeon, taverns, caves, city streets.

“Vintage Vault” is about recreating those classic video games and even board games. Everything in the game is recreated here in tile form. Relive the adventures of old or create new ones.

“Lost Realms” are deluxe sets. They're created just like a D&D module. There is an adventure theme already set out for a DM to build upon. So, these sets are heavily themed for instant adventuring.

description.text:
My other Anet a8 had printed bearings ii did have issues with them as the ID was too small and the OD was to big. My solution was to design my own, these are a snug fit so try not to squish the first layer the best you can. I printed mine in ABS as it's the only thing I really use but you can use anything I guess. Make sure to attach your belt before tightening the bolts for the blocks to insure a smooth movement. I also do a break in print for the first run of them, along with a nice soak in oil before installation.

FIX: I was having fitment issues has the first set of bearings were too snug I redesigned and did he second set to have a less snug fit to just smoothly glide along the rods. The files have been updated with the new verion, the new one doesn't have the lM8UU on them.

  • Shine towards the print bed not your eyes.

comments.text:
Hi Totsuka!
I'll have to admit that I didn't know that program. I've installed it just now, banged my head a little bit on the wall, and found the solution:
LaserWeb4 importing system seems a little bit wacky.. but it accepts well dxf files in R12 ASCII format. It's an old format, so not all programs export to it, and all my dxf files are in R14.
Still, you have Draftsight, a free CAD program from Dassault Systemes, that exports ok to R12 ASCII and consequently to LaserWeb4.
Hope this helps!

description.text:
I'm a little late to post this model - it is my interpretation back in 2016 (before Elon's talk) of what the SpaceX BFR spaceship might have looked like. I figured the ship would need a "broadside" heatshield like the shuttle, several vacuum engines for redundancy, strong legs for robust landings, and settling engines.

The shape ended up being completely different (more tube shaped and less delta) but the concept was pretty similar. Look at my other things for the more accurate BFR design concepts from 2016 and 2017.

This model prints without supports!

remixed_from.author: AllCity-Maker
remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi Zero Flex Camera Case

title: Pi 0 Flex case for mini camera

description.text:
I very much liked Allcity Maker's case, but needed to adapt it for the mini-camera. The cable for this is too long for the original design, and too short to fold, so I moved the camera mount to one end of the case.

When I came to put it together, most of the vertical pillars broke. I just don't seem to get on with thin vertical bits: they invariably come out the wrong size and, when I try to clean them up, they fall off.

I redesigned the Pi mount so it's held from both sides and has a shorter thin section. I had so much trouble with the camera mount, I put in a solid base with 2mm sockets. I inserted short pieces of cocktail stick into the sockets to hold the camera. Purists will cringe, but it works.

I also enlarged the GPIO socket to take an IDC header.

comments.text: Nice work!  I'm glad you could improve the design and make it work for you!

author: tobe81cwb

description.text:
First, at 2001, I wanted to design the entire temple but gave up as I found the video quality for walk through sequences would not be as good as I expected.
There are some renderings from this time as well.

The magnificent temple on the Acropolis of Athens, known as the Parthenon, was built between 447 and 432 BCE in the Age of Pericles, and it was dedicated to the city’s patron deity Athena. The temple was constructed to house the new cult statue of the goddess by Phidias and to proclaim to the world the success of Athens as leader of the coalition of Greek forces which had defeated the invading Persian armies of Darius and Xerxes.

Over the centuries this temple experienced turbulent history.
This video is a very good simulation to see what happened.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aGitmYl6U90
If you are interested in architecture you can watch a simulation of the construction with all details, like I first wanted to do ;-)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I6Wl4vyRqvw

This printable model represents a section of the north-western corner of the temple of
Parthenon, scaled 1 to 50.
It is an accurate reproduction based on drawings I could buy 2001 from the Archaeological
Society in Athens, called The Architecture of Parthenon ('Η ἀρχιτεκτονική τοῦ Παρθενῶνος').
A few slight modifications were administered to make the parts printable.
o be precise: As the columns lean a bit inward and the tilted axis of these columns
converge one and a half mile up in the sky, the floor actually has a spherical surface,
but was flattened by me for printing ease.

Each column of this model is different in diameter. All consist of 11 drums. This is
visibly marked by grooves, different for each column.
Furthermore, the diverging distances between the columns were averaged by me to appear constant and allow for extension on both sides.

Recommended print settings (I printed all parts with a 0.5mm nozzle)
All parts of the architrave, attic, column base, capital:
extrusion width = 0,4mm, layer hight = 0,2mm, 2 perimeter, 3 solid bottom layer, 4 solid top layer, 15% infill
Triglyphs
extrusion width = 0,4mm, layer hight = 0,2mm, 1 perimeter, 21 solid bottom layer, spiral vase, 0% infill
Columns
extrusion width = 0,45mm, layer hight = 0,15mm, 1 perimeter, 4 solid bottom layer, spiral vase, 0% infill
Stairs
extrusion width = 0,5mm, layer hight = 0,2mm, 1 perimeter, 3 solid bottom layer, spiral vase, 0% infill
Joint 2.6x15 and joining rail
extrusion width = 0,5mm, layer hight = 0,3mm, 1 perimeter, spiral vase, 0% infill
Joint 4.6x4.6x10
extrusion width = 0,4mm, layer hight = 0,2mm, 2 perimeter, 3 solid bottom layer, 3 solid top layer

What an amazing project. Are you going to finish the temple?
